key_mistakes.reason: The move c6 is passive, allowing White to occupy the center. It does not contest the center as effectively as other moves.
Inaccurate pawn move that doesn't develop pieces or challenge White's center effectively.
This move allows White to strengthen their pawn structure and gain a significant advantage.
Misses the opportunity to capture the pawn and solidify a central advantage.
This move loses material by allowing the opponent to capture a well-placed knight.
This move weakens the pawn structure and allows White to gain a winning position.
Misplaces the knight and allows the opponent to gain control of the board.
This move does not contribute to promoting the remaining pawns or improving king safety.
Misses a chance to create an immediate threat and simplify into a winning endgame.

recommendations: Focus on controlling the center early in the game.
Develop pieces actively to improve board control and coordination.
Avoid unnecessary pawn moves that weaken your structure without gaining a compensating advantage.
In endgames, prioritize pawn promotion and king safety.
Review tactical motifs to recognize opportunities and threats more effectively.
